content: SECTION 1. TERRITORIAL AND FREELY ASSOCIATED STATE INFRASTRUCTURE ASSISTANCE. Section 4(b) of Public Law 94-241 is amended to limit payments to the Commonwealth of the Northern Mariana Islands for fiscal years 1996 and beyond to amounts specified in the multi-year funding agreements. The multi-year funding agreements for the Northern Mariana Islands are limited to specified amounts set in the Agreement of the Special Representatives, subject to all requirements of the Agreement. Additional amounts in any fiscal year not needed for scheduled payments will be provided unless Congress decides otherwise. The special representatives of the Governor of the Northern Mariana Islands are subject to the Agreement's requirements. Additional amounts in any fiscal year not required for scheduled payments will be provided as specified by law. These additional amounts will be allocated for capital infrastructure projects in American Samoa for fiscal year 1996, and for fiscal years 1997 and beyond. For fiscal year 1996, additional amounts will be provided for capital infrastructure projects in American Samoa. For fiscal years 1997 and beyond, these amounts will be allocated solely for capital infrastructure projects in Guam, the Virgin Islands, American Samoa, the Commonwealth of the Northern Mariana Islands, the Republic of Palau, the Federated States of Micronesia, and the Republic of the Marshall Islands. In fiscal year 1997, $3 million will be allocated for capital infrastructure projects in Guam, the Virgin Islands, American Samoa, the Commonwealth of the Northern Mariana Islands, the Republic of Palau, the Federated States of Micronesia, and the Republic of the Marshall Islands. Additionally, $3 million will be available to the College of the Northern Marianas, with a provision for not exceeding $3 million annually for use by Federal agencies or the Commonwealth. In fiscal year 1997, $3 million will be allocated to the College of the Northern Marianas for infrastructure assistance to address immigration, labor, and law enforcement issues in the Northern Mariana Islands. This funding may be used for detention and corrections needs as outlined in a five-year plan. The Secretary of the Interior will develop a five-year plan for infrastructure assistance in consultation with the island governments of the Northern Mariana Islands to address immigration, labor, and law enforcement issues, including detention and corrections needs. The plan will be updated annually and submitted to Congress along with the Department of the Interior's budget justifications. The Secretary of the Interior, in consultation with island governments, will develop a five-year plan for capital infrastructure needs, indicating priority projects and considering master plans and Corps of Engineers' recommendations. Maintenance set-asides will also be considered. The Secretary of the Interior, in consultation with island governments, will develop a five-year plan for capital infrastructure needs, prioritizing projects based on master plans, Corps of Engineers' recommendations, maintenance set-asides, local cost-share requirements, and proposing an emergency fund of up to $2 million per year without fiscal year limitation. The Secretary of the Interior, in consultation with island governments, will develop a five-year plan for capital infrastructure needs, prioritizing projects based on master plans, Corps of Engineers' recommendations, and local cost-share requirements. An emergency fund of up to $2 million per year, without fiscal year limitation, may be proposed for natural disasters or other emergencies, with a cumulative limit of $10 million. Within the infrastructure allocation, additional funds can be provided for the resettlement of Rongelap Atoll, with a total federal contribution limit of $32 million since January 1, 1995. The emergency fund for natural disasters or emergencies has a cumulative limit of $10 million. Additional contributions may be made to assist in the resettlement of Rongelap Atoll, with a total federal contribution limit of $32 million since January 1, 1995. The funds must be used solely for resettlement activities and will be subject to proper auditing and accounting. The President must approve contributions as full settlement for US obligations to assist in Rongelap Atoll resettlement. Federal agencies in the Marshall Islands can provide funds through the Secretary of the Interior for resettlement. No limitations on assistance activities. Federal agencies in the Republic of the Marshall Islands can make funds available for the resettlement of Rongelap through the Secretary of the Interior. Assistance can also be provided to individuals choosing not to resettle at Rongelap, pending notification to Congress by the Secretary. Ex gratia assistance under the Compact of Free Association Act of 1985 can be provided to individuals not resettling at Rongelap, once all funds for resettlement are secured. SEC. 2. FEDERAL MINIMUM WAGE. Effective thirty days after enactment, the minimum wage provisions of the Fair Labor Standards Act will apply to the Commonwealth of the Northern Mariana Islands, with minimum wage rates set at $2.75 per hour initially, increasing to $3.05 per hour in 1996. The minimum wage rate for the Commonwealth of the Northern Mariana Islands will be $2.75 per hour initially, increasing to $3.05 per hour in 1996, and then raised by thirty cents per hour every January 1 thereafter until it reaches the wage rate set forth in the Fair Labor Standards Act. The minimum wage rate for the Commonwealth of the Northern Mariana Islands will be increased by thirty cents per hour annually until it reaches the wage rate set forth in the Fair Labor Standards Act. Once it equals the FLSA rate, it will remain at that level. The text chunk "SEC. 3. REPORT." is a concise summary of the section regarding reporting in the context of the minimum wage rate increase in the Commonwealth of the Northern Mariana Islands. The Secretary of the Interior, in consultation with other relevant departments, must report to Congress by March 15 each fiscal year on funds allocated for immigration, labor, and law enforcement activities in the CNMI. The report includes immigration data, such as the number of non-US citizen contract workers in the CNMI. The report to Congress on funds allocated for immigration, labor, and law enforcement activities in the CNMI must include immigration information provided by the Immigration and Naturalization Service, treatment and conditions of non-US citizen contract workers, and foreign government interference with workers' rights. The report to Congress on funds allocated for immigration, labor, and law enforcement activities in the CNMI must include information on non-US citizen contract workers, foreign government interference, Federal interests, detention facilities, and the alien identification system. The report to Congress must address the impact of Northern Mariana Islands laws on Federal interests, the adequacy of detention facilities, the reliability of the alien identification system, and reasons for Federal agencies' enforcement challenges without funding from the Secretary of the Interior. SEC. 4. Immigration cooperation between the Commonwealth of the Northern Mariana Islands and Immigration and Naturalization Service to identify and potentially exclude or deport individuals posing security or law enforcement risks. SEC. 5. Clarification of local employment in the Marianas. Section 8103(i) of title 46 of the United States Code is amended to allow aliens in the Commonwealth of the Northern Mariana Islands to work as unlicensed seamen on certain vessels within the US waters surrounding the CNMI. Aliens in the Commonwealth of the Northern Mariana Islands can work as unlicensed seamen on fishing vessels within US waters surrounding the CNMI, with permission from the Attorney General of the United States. Aliens in the Commonwealth of the Northern Mariana Islands can work as unlicensed seamen on fishing vessels within US waters surrounding the CNMI with permission from the Attorney General of the United States. Section 8103(i)(1) of title 46 of the United States Code is amended to update the subsection reference. SEC. 6. CLARIFICATION OF OWNERSHIP OF SUBMERGED LANDS IN THE COMMONWEALTH OF THE NORTHERN MARIANA ISLANDS. Public Law 93-435 (88 Stat. 1210) is amended by including the Commonwealth of the Northern Mariana Islands in various sections previously mentioning Guam and the Virgin Islands. Amendments are made to Public Law 93-435 by including the Commonwealth of the Northern Mariana Islands in sections previously mentioning Guam and the Virgin Islands. The references to enactment dates in the law now apply to the date of enactment of this specific section. The Secretary of the Interior must provide an annual report to Congress on the economic development, federal assistance, local finances, infrastructure, and financial management of various US territories and Pacific island nations. Section 501 of Public Law 95-134 is amended to include the Republic of Palau, the Republic of the Marshall Islands, and the Federated States of Micronesia. Passed by the Senate on July 20, 1995.
